content.description: Sit start on huecos, up the very brief vertical bit to lower angle climbing with small holds.
content.location: Obvious pockets on the left side of the little east face of the boulder. See Ursa Major East Face beta photo, problem #10.

content.description: Sit start using pretty good left hand sidepull and whatever you can stick your right hand to. Go up a very blunt arete feature using some tiny holds, to better holds higher up.
content.location: Left of center on the south face the base of the boulder transitions to slightly overhung. Start here. See Ursa Major South Face beta photo, problem #7.

content.description: Sit start matched on a nice, angled jug. Go up through techy moves to a massive jug high out left, or directly up to the high point (spicier).
content.protection: Pads and spotters, it's tall with an uneven landing
content.location: Towards the right end of the west face, almost directly under the highest point. See Ursa Major West Face beta photo, problem #4.

content.description: Sit start with hands in good huecos and so-so feet. Watch out for the cholla needles in the pack rat collection here! Make a few lateral moves out right through crimps to gain the good right hand edge for the stand start of this problem, then go up.
content.location: Beside the plant at the left end of the west face, just above a hole with pack rat debris. See Ursa Major West Face beta photo, problem #2.

content.description: Sit start matched in the hueco, work right up the SE arete to ledge above.
content.location: Near the right end of the south face is a hueco about 3 feet off the ground, start here. See Ursa Major South beta photo, problem #9.

content.description: Stand start using a small left hand sidepull crimp and right hand edge/pocket. A couple of hard moves right away with poor feet will lead to jugs on the lower angle, easy upper face. The easy top section makes it feel not-so-tall.
content.protection: Pads and a spotter, it's tall
content.location: Left of center on the west face of the boulder.  See Ursa Major West Face beta photo, problem #3.

content.description: It's vertical for a few feet right off the ground, then eases up to a very easy angle.
content.protection: Maybe a pad and a spotter
content.location: On the NE corner of the boulder is a low angle ramp. See Ursa Major East Face beta photo, problem #12.

content.description: This standalone boulder offers a dozen problems, mostly easy but some are tall. It has climbing on all sides and gets lots of sun throughout the day, once the sun has crested the ridge to the east in the morning.
